metadata.case_name: State of Bihar v. Bipat Gope

facts.text: Bipat Gope convicted under s. 323, s. 324 read with s. 511 IPC and sentenced on November 29, 1957, to six months rigorous imprisonment by Patna High Court on appeal against acquittal under s. 417 CrPC.
Bipat Gope not taken into custody till January 6, 1958, and kept under armed guard in Patna Medical College Hospital paying ward due to serious illness.
Bipat Gope released by District Magistrate on March 11, 1958, on application by respondent and recommendation of medical authority, with unexpired sentence of four months and three days.
State contends release under R. 549 Jail Manual (conditional release); respondent challenges factum of release under this rule.
Sureties called to produce Bipat Gope; on failure, notices issued on April 27, 1958, to show cause why surety bonds should not be forfeited; non-bailable warrant ordered.
Bipat Gope moved petition under Art. 226 on April 29, 1958; High Court directed appearance on May 5, 1958.

On May 1, 1958, Bipat Gope appeared before District Magistrate, applied stating High Court petition filed and apprehension of maltreatment by police; ordered into custody by Senior Deputy Collector and sent to jail.
Earlier High Court petition withdrawn on May 2, 1958.
High Court heard petition on May 5, 1958, allowed it after amendments, ordered release holding District Magistrate's order was unconditional.
Medical certificates: Dr. V.N. Sinha on Feb 21, 1958, stated not improving; Civil Surgeon inquiry March 1; March 3 complications fatal; March 5 in danger of death but likely to improve if released.
Judicial Peshkar note referred to Jail Manual Rules 548(1)(2)(3) and 549; DM order 'Allowed release in the circumstances' dated March 7, 1958.
Release in Form No. 105 mentioning Rules 548, 549, 552 (none scored out); sureties bound to surrender by July 9, 1958.
No return filed by State to High Court rule; unclear authority for rearrest by Senior Deputy Collector.

legal_issues.text: Whether Bipat Gope was released under R. 549 Jail Manual (conditional) or unconditionally, and whether there was lawful authority for his rearrest and detention.

petitioner_arguments.text: Release of Bipat Gope was under R. 549 Jail Manual, which provides for conditional release; sureties bound to produce him.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Jail Manual R. 549, Prisons Act; Form 105

petitioner_arguments.text: Seeks opinion on true meaning and extent of Rule 549.

respondent_arguments.text: Release by District Magistrate was unconditional; challenges factum of release under R. 549.

court_reasoning.text: Not clear from record under which rule Bipat Gope was released; neither DM order nor Form 105 specifies R. 549 exclusively.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No proper return or affidavit by State clarifying rule of release or authority for rearrest.

court_reasoning.text: No lawful authority shown for rearrest by Senior Deputy Collector or detention; State failed to file proper return.
court_reasoning.key_observation: In absence of lawful authority, detention illegal; cites Eshugbayi Eleko on executive not interfering with liberty without legal support.

holdings.text: Detention of Bipat Gope cannot be supported and is illegal in absence of shown lawful authority for rearrest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Eshugbayi Eleko v. The Officer Administering The Government of Nigeria
precedents_cited.relevance: No member of executive can interfere with liberty except on condition of supporting legality before court; tradition of British justice adopted in India.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Proceedings under Art. 226 for habeas corpus; appeal under Art. 134(1)(c) dismissed by HC.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Habeas corpus petition; appeal against acquittal.

statutes_cited.name: Prisons Act / Jail Manual
statutes_cited.relevance: Rules for release on medical grounds; dispute over conditional vs. unconditional release.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court holds that in absence of proper return and shown lawful authority, Bipat Gope's detention is illegal, upholding High Court order for his release.
outcome.relief_granted: Bipat Gope's release from custody affirmed.

key_quotes.text: "In accordance with British jurisprudence no member of the executive can interfere with the liberty or property of a British subject except on the condition that he can support the legality of his action before a Court of justice."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes principle that executive must justify detention legally; applied to find detention illegal.

key_quotes.text: "It has not been shown in this case that there was any lawful authority under which Bipat Gope was rearrested and in the absence of such lawful authority Bipat Gope's detention cannot be supported and is illegal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on illegality of detention.
